questions.text: Pencil shaped macroconidia are seen in? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichophyton

 

Explanation:

 

Pencil-shaped macroconidia are a distinguishing feature of the fungus Trichophyton. Trichophyton is one of the three genera of dermatophytes, which also include Microsporum and Epidermophyton.

 

Dermatophytes cause infections known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, which affect keratinized tissues such as the skin, hair, and nails.

 

Dermatophytosis can be classified into three species:

 

  1. Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped).  In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes.
  2. Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent.
  3. Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Microsporum: The macroconidia of Microsporum are spindle-shaped and spiny, not pencil-shaped. This genus primarily affects skin and hair.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton: The macroconidia of Epidermophyton are club-shaped, not pencil-shaped. This genus affects skin and nails.

 

Option D. Clostridium: This is a genus of bacteria, not fungi, and it does not produce macroconidia. Clostridium species are known for producing spores, not conidia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pencil-shaped macroconidia are characteristic of Trichophyton, a genus of dermatophytes that affects skin, hair, and nails.

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows height for age < -2 SD. What is the appropriate term for the above mentioned condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stunting

 

This is the correct answer. Stunting refers to impaired growth in height for age. If a child's height falls below -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median on growth charts, it indicates chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wasting: Wasting refers to low weight for height and is an indicator of acute malnutrition. It is assessed by comparing a child's weight to a reference standard for their height.

 

Option C. Severe Acute Malnutrition: While this term is related to malnutrition, it specifically refers to a combination of wasting and other clinical signs. Stunting alone does not categorize a child as having severe acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. Kwashiorkor: Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by protein deficiency. It often presents with edema, skin changes, and hepatomegaly. Stunting, as described in the scenario, is not a characteristic feature of kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the different indicators of malnutrition, specifically recognizing that height for age < -2 SD is a sign of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment â€“

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best test to arrive at a definitive diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sestamibi scan

 

The patient's symptoms of bone pain, abdominal cramps, and a history of abnormal behavior are indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. This condition is often described by the phrase "stones, bones, groans, and moans," referring to kidney stones, bone pain, abdominal symptoms, and psychological manifestations, respectively.

 

Primary hyperparathyroidism is most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia. To localize the abnormal parathyroid gland(s), the Sestamibi scan is the best diagnostic test. This nuclear medicine scan uses a radiotracer that is absorbed by overactive parathyroid tissue, allowing for accurate localization.

 

Technetium-99m scan but, Sestamibi scan is better

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While useful for imaging soft tissues, it is not the best choice for localizing hyperparathyroid tissue.

 

Option B. Ultrasonogram: Can help in identifying enlarged parathyroid glands but is less sensitive and specific compared to the Sestamibi scan.

 

Option D. CT scan: Useful for detailed imaging of various structures but not the best for identifying hyperparathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sestamibi scan is the best diagnostic test for localizing abnormal parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: In CN III palsy, which of the following is not affected? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

Cranial Nerve III (CN III), also known as the oculomotor nerve, innervates several muscles responsible for eye movements and eyelid elevation. These muscles include the superior rectus (elevation), medial rectus (adduction), inferior rectus (depression), and inferior oblique (extorsion and elevation in adduction). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eyelid.

 

Abduction is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI), not the oculomotor nerve. Therefore, abduction is not affected in CN III palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

In CN III palsy, the functions of these muscles are compromised, leading to issues such as:

 

Option A. Elevation: Elevation is affected due to the involvement of the superior rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option B. Adduction: Adduction is affected due to the involvement of the medial rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CN III palsy, abduction is not affected because it is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI).

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: IUCD can be inserted after delivery till? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 48hrs


An Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD), specifically the Copper T, can be inserted immediately after delivery as part of postpartum family planning. The optimal time frames for insertion include:

 

  1. Post-placental insertion: Within 10 minutes of placental delivery, commonly done when the patient is highly motivated.
  2. Early postpartum insertion: From 10 minutes up to 48 hours after delivery.
  3. Intra-caesarean insertion: At the time of cesarean section.
  4. Late postpartum – After 6 weeks 

 

Early postpartum IUCD insertion is considered safe and effective during this period due to the lower risk of expulsion and higher motivation of the patient.

 

Note -  48hrs to 6 weeks’ period is not suitable for IUCD insertion due to the high risk of expulsion and complications as the uterus is actively involuting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery, but not between 48 hours to 6 weeks due to the high risk of expulsion during this time.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

 

  1. Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  2. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs.
  3. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
  4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Explanation

 

The true statements are:

 

Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.

 

Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.

 

Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first-line drug used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. The hallmark of this condition is fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.

 

The primary mechanism involves antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between nerves and muscles.

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Pyridostigmine works by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing communication between nerves and muscles, which helps to improve muscle strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system. While it can be used in myasthenia gravis, it is not the first-line treatment. It is typically considered when patients do not adequately respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: An immunosuppressant that can be used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in patients who are not responsive to corticosteroids or those who have significant side effects from steroids. It is not a first-line treatment due to its side effect profile

 

Option D. Plasma exchange: This is a procedure used in severe cases of myasthenia gravis or during myasthenic crisis. It rapidly reduces the level of circulating antibodies by removing them from the blood. This is not used as a first-line treatment but rather as an acute intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate for this patient for prophylaxis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

 

During pregnancy, the choice of anticoagulant therapy is crucial due to the risks associated with both the mother and the developing fetus. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the drug of choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy across all trimesters. It is preferred because it does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus, and it has a lower risk of causing bleeding complications compared to other anticoagulants.

 

In this specific case of a woman at 30 weeks of gestation diagnosed with DVT, LMWH is the most appropriate choice for prophylaxis. Warfarin, although sometimes used in the second trimester, is generally avoided due to its teratogenic effects, particularly during the first trimester and closer to delivery.

 

Newer anticoagulants like Apixaban and Fondaparinux are not typically recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient evidence of safety and potential risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin can be used during the second trimester up to 36 weeks if necessary. However, it is typically avoided in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can cause fetal complications, especially if used in the first trimester or near term.

 

Option C. Apixaban: Apixaban, a newer oral anticoagulant, is generally avoided in pregnancy due to a lack of sufficient data supporting its safety for the fetus.

 

Option D. Fondaparinux: Although Fondaparinux has a lower risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), it is not the first-line choice during pregnancy. The data on its safety in pregnancy are limited, and therefore, LMWH is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for both the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT during pregnancy across all trimesters due to its safety profile for both the mother and fetus.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

choices.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation
Preserve in envelope or paper bag
Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together
Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

 

When handling blood-stained handkerchiefs or any other stained items found at a crime scene, it is crucial to follow the appropriate procedure to ensure the preservation of evidence. The most suitable method is to preserve the handkerchiefs in an envelope or paper bag, which allows for air circulation. This prevents the growth of mold and bacteria that can occur when moisture is trapped in non-porous containers like plastic bags.

 

Additionally, it is important to dry the stains, but this should be done in the shade or by air drying. Exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat can denature the DNA, compromising the evidence. Therefore, using a spirit lamp or any other heating material to dry the stains is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A & D. Place them in same/different plastic bag and seal it for preservation: Plastic bags should be avoided as they can trap moisture, leading to the growth of mold and bacteria, which can compromise the evidence.

 

Option. C. Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together: Folding the handkerchiefs with the stained edges together can lead to the mixing of stains, making it difficult to distinguish between the stains from different individuals, if applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 6

 

The Delphian lymph node is a prelaryngeal lymph node located just above the thyroid isthmus. In the classification of neck lymph nodes, it is part of:

 

Also known as the central compartment, Level 6 includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) lymph nodes. This is the correct level for the Delphian lymph node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 3-4: These typically refer to the middle and lower jugular lymph nodes, which are located along the mid and lower third of the internal jugular vein.

 

Option B. Levels 1-2: Level 1 includes the submental and submandibular nodes, and Level 2 includes the upper jugular lymph nodes. These are not the locations of the Delphian lymph node.

 

Option C. Level 5: This includes the posterior triangle group of lymph nodes, located along the lower half of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, extending into the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: Preservative commonly used for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formalin

 

  • Chemical for preservation for histopathology samples: Formalin. But it is not used as preservative for Toxicological analysis because extraction of poison becomes difficult.
  • Chemicals used for Preservation of Viscera for Toxicological analysis: Anyone of the following two preservatives may be used:

 

1) Saturated solution of common salt (NaCl, i.e. sodium chloride):

 

  1. Most commonly used preservative (easily available & cheap)
  2. It is indicated in all poisoning cases except Corrosives

 

2) Rectified spirit:

 

  1. Best preservative
  2. Indicated for most of the poisons except alcohol, acetic acid, Chloral hydrate, Chloroform, formaldehyde, formic acid, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, Phenol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl Alcohol: Not commonly used for histopathological tissue preservation due to its dehydration properties, which can alter tissue morphology.

 

Option C. Saturated Salt Solution: Commonly used as a preservative for toxicological analysis. It is easy to obtain and cost-effective. However, it is not suitable for preserving tissue for histopathology because it does not adequately preserve tissue morphology and detail.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Primarily used for medical procedures and as a temporary transport medium. It does not provide the long-term preservation needed for histopathological examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formalin is the preservative of choice for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination due to its ability to maintain tissue morphology and cellular details.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

 

  • The image shows hesitation cuts.
  • It is a series of shallow cuts made by people considering a suicide attempt.
  • These wounds are often multiple, parallel, non-lethal cuts.
  • The throat, and wrist are the most common sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grazed abrasion: Grazed abrasions occur when the skin is rubbed or scraped against a rough surface, leading to the removal of the superficial layers of the skin. This does not match the image shown, which depicts clean, linear cuts.

 

Option C. Laceration: Lacerations are deeper tears or cuts in the skin caused by blunt trauma. They are typically irregular and have abraded edges. The image shows clean, linear cuts, not consistent with lacerations.

 

Option D. Patterned bruise: Patterned bruises are caused by an object leaving a distinct pattern on the skin, such as from a belt or other implement. The marks in the image are linear and clean, not consistent with the diffuse and patterned nature of bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

choices.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years
600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

 

For secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever, especially in patients without carditis or valvulitis, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines recommend administering benzathine penicillin G for either 5 years or until the patient is 21 years old, whichever is longer. Given that the child in this case is 11 years old, prophylaxis should continue until the child turns 21, resulting in a total duration of 10 years.

 

The dosage of benzathine penicillin G depends on the patient's weight:

 

  • For children weighing less than 27 kg, the dose is 600,000 IU.
  • For children weighing 27 kg or more, the dose is 1,200,000 IU.

 

Since the child weighs 26 kg, the appropriate dose is 600,000 IU. In high-risk areas such as India, the injection is administered every 3 weeks to ensure effective prophylaxis against recurrent streptococcal infections that could lead to rheumatic fever.

 

Note - Treatment duration options for a patient with valvulitis:

 

  • Standard Treatment Duration: Patients can be treated for a total duration of 10 years or until they reach the age of 40, whichever comes later. This approach is likely considered for cases where the valve damage is not extensively severe or life-threatening.
  • Severe Valve Damage: If there is severe damage to the valves, such as cases leading to or involving heart failure, lifelong therapy is recommended. This could include ongoing medication to manage the condition and potentially surgical interventions like valve replacement to address the mechanical deficits caused by the damage.

 

Note –

  • First-Line Therapy:
    • Injectable Penicillin: Typically administered once every 3 to 4 weeks.
    • Oral Alternative or if the patient prefers not to receive injections, Penicillin V can be used orally at a dose of 250 mg BD.
  • Second-Line Therapy (For patients with Penicillin Allergy): Sulfadiazine
  • Third-Line Therapy (For patients with both Penicillin and Sulfa Allergies): Macrolides (Either erythromycin or azithromycin, with erythromycin typically prescribed at 250 mg BD)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years: This option would be correct if the duration were 5 years, but since the patient must receive prophylaxis until age 21, this is insufficient.

 

Option C. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years: This dosage is for children weighing 27 kg or more. Since the child in this case weighs 26 kg, this dose is too high.

 

Option D. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life: Lifelong prophylaxis with this dosage is only indicated in patients with severe valvular damage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

questions.text: The most common organ that injures in air blast-shock wave is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the most common organs injured are the tympanic membrane (eardrums), lungs, and gastrointestinal tract (GIT), in that order. Since the tympanic membrane is not included in the given answer options, the correct answer among the available choices is the lungs, which are the second most commonly affected organ in an air blast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Kidney: Although the kidneys can be injured in an air blast, they are not the most common organ affected.

 

Option. C. Bones: While fractures can occur due to the impact of an air blast, bones are not the most frequently injured structures compared to the lungs.

 

Option. D. Skeletal muscle: Skeletal muscle injuries can happen in an air blast, but they are not the most common type of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the lungs are the most common organ injured among the given options, following the tympanic membrane. In contrast, the gastrointestinal tract is the most frequently affected organ in underwater blast injuries.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose


In patients with a history of chronic alcohol intake, thiamine deficiency is a common complication. Alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to deficiencies that can impact various metabolic processes, including carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA during glucose metabolism. Administering glucose without prior thiamine can precipitate acute thiamine deficiency symptoms, worsening the patientâ€™s condition and potentially leading to Wernickeâ€™s encephalopathy, a severe neurological disorder.

 

Therefore, in cases where hypoglycemia is present (as indicated by a plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL), the correct management is to first administer thiamine to replenish depleted stores and then follow with dextrose to correct the hypoglycemia safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: While dextrose is necessary to treat hypoglycemia, administering it before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can worsen the deficiency, leading to serious neurological complications.

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is used in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not relevant in alcohol-induced hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine: While thiamine is part of the treatment, it alone does not correct hypoglycemia. Both thiamine and dextrose are necessary, in the correct order.

 

Educational Objective:


In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ER with menorrhagia. She mentions that her father and sister also suffer from bleeding disorders. Which of the following is likely? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von Willebrand Disease

 

Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most likely diagnosis given the family history of bleeding disorders and the patient's presentation with menorrhagia. vWD is an autosomal dominant condition affecting both males and females, characterized by defective platelet function due to a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. This leads to symptoms such as prolonged bleeding, menorrhagia, and prolonged bleeding after dental extractions or surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor X deficiency: An extremely rare autosomal recessive condition that typically presents with joint bleeding (hemarthrosis) and intramuscular hematomas, which are more indicative of coagulation disorders rather than bleeding tendencies seen in platelet disorders.

 

Option B. Factor VIII deficiency: Known as Hemophilia A, this is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males. Females are typically carriers and rarely show symptoms. Hemophilia A presents with severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not usually menorrhagia.

 

Option C. Factor IX deficiency: Known as Hemophilia B, this is also an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males, with similar presentations to Hemophilia A, including severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not typically menorrhagia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand Disease is an autosomal dominant disorder presenting with bleeding symptoms like menorrhagia and is more common in females compared to Hemophilia A or B, which are X-linked recessive and primarily affect males.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CDR

 

Explanation:

 

The mid-year population is used as the denominator to calculate the Crude Death Rate (CDR). The CDR is calculated as the total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because. It is calculated as Annual number of live births per 1000 women of childbearing age (15â€“49 years) mid-year population

 

Option C. MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) - This option is incorrect because the MMR is calculated as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Option D. NMR (Neonatal Mortality Rate) - This option is incorrect because the NMR is calculated as neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-year population is the denominator used in the calculation of the Crude Death Rate (CDR), which represents the total number of deaths per 1,000 population in a given year or period.

questions.text: In the image provided, which muscle is most likely represented by the blue-colored area? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the base of the second metacarpal bone on the dorsal side.
  • Action: This muscle extends and abducts the wrist. It helps in the extension of the wrist joint and also assists in radial abduction.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the radial nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brachioradialis:

 

  • Origin: This muscle originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the lateral surface of the radius near its styloid process.
  • Action: The primary function is to flex the elbow. However, unlike most other flexors of the elbow, which are pronators, the brachioradialis is a supinator when the forearm is pronated and a pronator when the forearm is supinated, making it a neutralizer of the forearm.
  • Innervation: The brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Supinator:

 

  • Origin: The supinator muscle has a two-headed origin â€“ one from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (by the radial collateral ligament) and one from the proximal ulna (from the annular ligament and the supinator crest).
  • Insertion: It wraps around the upper third of the radius.
  • Action: As its name suggests, it supinates the forearm, meaning it rotates the forearm to turn the palm anteriorly or upwards.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis brevis:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.
  • Action: This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery â€“ it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, â€˜annulus of Vieussenâ€™sâ€™.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadockâ€™s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.text: Which item is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adulteration of food

 

The concurrent list in the Indian Constitution includes subjects on which both the central and state governments can legislate. One of the items included in this list is the adulteration of food. The legislative framework in India is divided into three lists as per the seventh schedule of the Constitution:

 

  1. Union List: Contains subjects on which only the Parliament can make laws. This list includes 100 items, such as defense, foreign affairs, atomic energy, and others.
  2. State List: Contains subjects on which only the state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 61 items, such as police, public health, and agriculture.
  3. Concurrent List: Contains subjects on which both the Parliament and state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 52 items, such as criminal law, marriage and divorce, bankruptcy and insolvency, and the adulteration of food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This subject is included in the Union List, meaning that only the Parliament has the authority to legislate on this matter.

 

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This subject is also included in the Union List, placing it under the legislative jurisdiction of the Parliament.

 

Option D. Public health and sanitation: This subject is included in the State List, meaning that only state governments have the exclusive authority to legislate on public health and sanitation matters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution, allowing both the central and state governments to legislate on this issue. The Union List and State List contain subjects exclusive to the Parliament and state legislatures, respectively.

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 46 XX

 

The scenario describes a patient with primary amenorrhea, secondary sexual characteristics, and a presence of the uterus and ovaries. The image shows an obstruction in the vaginal opening, which is likely an imperforate hymen. The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal internal reproductive organs, such as the uterus and ovaries, indicates that the chromosomal pattern is normal female, 46 XX. The karyotype is not affected by the physical obstruction causing the amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 45 XO: This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, where patients usually have streak ovaries, lack secondary sexual characteristics, and have other distinct features like webbed neck and short stature, none of which are present in this scenario.

 

Option C. 47 XXY: This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, typically found in males who present with hypogonadism, tall stature, and often gynecomastia. It is not applicable to the described scenario with a female presentation.

 

Option D. 46 XY: This karyotype is associated with male individuals or conditions like Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The presence of normal female internal reproductive structures (uterus and ovaries) rules out 46 XY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing. On examination, his FEV1% is significantly reduced. Based on this finding, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by chronic airflow limitation that is not fully reversible. It is commonly associated with a history of smoking and is diagnosed based on symptoms such as chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. The airflow obstruction in COPD is due to a combination of airway disease (chronic bronchitis) and parenchymal destruction (emphysema), leading to difficulty in exhaling air from the lungs.

 

In this case, the patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing, which are hallmark symptoms of COPD. The significant reduction in FEV1% further supports the diagnosis of an obstructive lung disease, where the primary issue is the narrowing of the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis - Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by the stiffening and scarring of lung tissue, which makes it difficult for the lungs to expand. FEV1% is typically preserved or increased in restrictive lung diseases, not significantly reduced as seen in obstructive lung diseases like COPD.

 

Option C. Asthma - While asthma is also an obstructive lung disease, it is usually characterized by reversible airway obstruction and presents with intermittent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and dry cough. Chronic productive cough is less common in asthma compared to COPD.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis - Sarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disease that primarily affects the lungs but presents with a variety of other systemic symptoms. It is more commonly associated with a restrictive pattern on lung function tests and does not typically present with a chronic productive cough or a significantly reduced FEV1% as seen in COPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a chronic productive cough, progressive difficulty in breathing, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. It is a common cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary symptoms in older adults, particularly those with a history of smoking.

choices.text: Fracture of the base of the skull

questions.text: A man is working in an industry without wearing a helmet. A heavy hammer falls on his head due to slipping from the head of his colleague working on the top floor. The X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depressed Fracture

 

A depressed fracture occurs when a heavy object with a small striking surface impacts the skull, causing a localized depression. In this scenario, the heavy hammer is the object that creates such a fracture. The X-ray provided shows a depression in the skull, indicative of a depressed fracture.

 

Note â€“

 

Ping Pong #/Ponds #/ Intended # - (a type of depressed #) This is a smooth concave depression without a fracture line, resulting from in-buckling of skull, occurring only in the elastic skull of infants.

 

Gutter # - Long narrow depressed #; It is formed when part of the thickness of the bone is removed so as to form a gutter, e.g. oblique bullet wounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linear Fracture/ primary #/ Fissured #: This type of fracture is a simple break in the bone, typically caused by a broad surface impact, such as falling on the ground. It is not usually caused by a hammer.

 

Option C. Fracture of the base of the skull: This type of fracture occurs in severe trauma situations, like road traffic accidents, esp. motorcyclists. Types are -

 

  • Ring # - fall from height; # around foramen magnum
  • Motorcyclist # / Hinge # - skull is divided into anterior and posterior half
  • Spider web #/ Mosaic #/ Comminuted # - Multiple # of skull

 

Option D. Sutural Fracture (Diastatic Fracture): This type occurs in children below three years of age when the sutures of the skull separate. It is not relevant to the described scenario of an adult in an industry.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A heavy object with a small striking surface, such as a hammer, typically causes a depressed fracture in the skull. â€‹
